<tei-div data-origname="div">
   <tei-head n="Aux sociétés ayant pour but l'abolition de l'esclavage, et aux amis de l'emancipation des noirs." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">TO THE SOCIETIES WHOSE AIM IS THE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY, AND TO THE FRIENDS OF THE EMANCIPATION OF NEGROES.</tei-head>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">Several friends of humanity have deemed it necessary to prolong the existence of the societies established for the defense and emancipation of Negroes.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">Although slavery is abolished, and probably forever in our colonies, not only must the manner of applying the measures ordered be supervised, but sustained efforts are still needed in order to protect, in the future, the Negro in the enjoyment of the rights that have been recognized for him. It has also been considered that, since slavery is proscribed by no other civilized nation, it is necessary to bring to bear the moral influence of <tei-placeName ref="#GB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Great Britain</tei-placeName> to effect everywhere its most immediate and most complete abolition possible. The profound conviction of our religious duties, which has enabled us to obtain so much success in our own country, must inspire in us the same zeal in seeking all legitimate means to attain the same end abroad. <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Slavery, wherever it exists, is the same moral deformity; it is the same crime before God</tei-emph>; and it must be regarded with execration and condemned with boldness by every man who professes the principles of Christianity.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">Moreover, there is rising at this moment in the Northern States of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Union</tei-orgName> a powerful and almost unforeseen interest in favor of the slaves.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">We believe we ought to cite here a few facts little known to the public.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">The number of slaves in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">America</tei-placeName> exceeds two million</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">In some places (as for example in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">South Carolina</tei-placeName>) education is forbidden to them by law, and a free man of color has no right to set foot on the territory. The testimony of a slave has no value, except when it serves to convict another slave. Trial by jury is not admitted there, even in capital cases. Finally, obstacles so insurmountable have been placed in the way of emancipation that even if a slaveholder, good and conscientious, wishes to rid himself of his iniquitous property, he has the law against him; he dares not, he cannot emancipate <tei-pb facs="v1n6f23" n="23" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>his slave unless he banishes him from his home and his family; for, to emancipate him, he must first take him to another state and exile him forever. The condition of free people of color in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">America</tei-placeName>, whose number exceeds 300,000, is also truly pitiable. Their acquired privileges are of little importance and little regarded, their degradation is intolerable, and their progressive banishment from the states is generally regarded as a maxim of national policy. We are still obliged to add that the traffic in human beings continues within the country with all the most abject and most disgusting incidents. Husbands and wives, mothers and children are publicly offered for sale, bargained over and examined like cattle, and then separated from one another forever, with the same indifference as if it were a matter of the sheep or oxen in our markets.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">It was easy to foresee that such a state of affairs could not fail to awaken in America the sympathy and indignation of the friends of humanity. But unfortunately people there are so accustomed to slavery, the national contempt for men of color has such deep roots, that to this day that indignation makes little progress, even in the Northern States, despite the most energetic efforts of worthy men. When they have tried to bring about a revolution in public opinion, they have encountered nowhere either encouragement or help.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">However, far from losing heart, they have recently established at <tei-placeName ref="#Phd" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Philadelphia</tei-placeName> a National Society for the abolition of slavery; unfortunately the number of members is too small in proportion to the immense extent of the country which must be the object of the Society’s labors, and the modesty of its pecuniary resources makes one fear great difficulties in pursuing this generous undertaking. This Society requests our assistance. Several of its members have been eyewitnesses to the miraculous successes that the blessing of the Almighty has permitted us to obtain in our country, and they have resolved to follow our example. Their aim is to spread their principles throughout all the States by the means of the press and preaching, to stir and direct the efforts of all men who profess the same principles, by creating associations affiliated with the central Society; they have decided, moreover, to adhere conscientiously to the principle that <tei-emph data-origname="emph">slavery, being a crime before God, must be abolished as such</tei-emph>, the principle that has always served as the basis of our actions.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">The committee could not remain indifferent to the appeal of this generous Society; and when the hope of joining with it and lending it help decided us to prolong the existence and action of our own, numerous letters, arriving from several parts of the country, enabled us to judge that our view of this great cause had found an echo throughout the country. In some places, the committee has even been surpassed; at <tei-placeName ref="#Lvp" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Liverpool</tei-placeName> and in <tei-placeName ref="#Ec" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Scotland</tei-placeName> especially, considerable sums have already been subscribed; and the need for a central committee to coordinate and set operations in motion was evident and indispensable. The committee assembled amid these circumstances and, after a considered examination of its future work, reorganized itself by adopting the name of <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">British and Foreign Society for the Universal Abolition of Negro Slavery and the Slave Trade</tei-emph></tei-orgName>.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">This title clearly sets out our aim, and we hope for the help and assistance of all good men in our country. We regard it as the first of our duties to support the abolition of slavery in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">America</tei-placeName> by all the means that can make it triumph; we shall send distinguished preachers, and we shall propagate, by every possible means, the lively interest that is beneficial to so worthy a cause.</tei-p>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">Society</tei-orgName> desires to become the organ of the voice of our enslaved and suffering brothers over the whole surface of the world. It will seek to unveil and bring to light the secrets of prisons and the cries of distress of the Negro exposed to the tortures of the tropical sun or chained in the abysses of the mines of Peru. We firmly believe that, by constantly arousing the attention of the public, we shall assist the protective influence that Parliament must retain over the rigorous observance of our laws and treaties, whose salutary provisions, intended to prevent the slave trade, often remain without execution in ministerial offices. We also believe that the impulse given by <tei-placeName ref="#GB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Great Britain</tei-placeName> will induce other countries to follow the noble example we offer them.</tei-p>

  <tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-p data-origname="p">We feel all that is difficult, even presumptuous, in our hopes; but is it possible to forget that the e<tei-pb facs="v1n6f24" n="24" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>mancipation of our colonies was regarded a few years ago as a dream of enthusiastic visionaries, or at most as an imaginary and impracticable utopia. Yet God has blessed our labors, though we had no other guides than the principles of Christianity, and no other aid than a few subscriptions. Encouraged by popular opinion, we have realized this dream of imagination, and after a few years colonial slavery has disappeared, if not everywhere and completely, at least forever in certain lands.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">Full of confidence in divine protection, and conscientiously relying on the same Christian principle, we shall seek no other means to obtain the far greater and nobler triumph to which we now aspire; and we declare that we are guided by the holy book of the Bible, in seeking to bring about THE COMPLETE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY IN THE WORLD, <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">“not by force, not by power, but by my spirit,” said the Lord of heaven</tei-emph>.</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">The president</tei-emph>, George STEPHEN. <tei-emph data-origname="emph">The secretary</tei-emph>, John SCOBLE.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">Persons who wish to assist <tei-orgName ref="#Soc" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">the Society</tei-orgName> are requested to send their subscriptions to <tei-emph data-origname="emph">M. Scoble</tei-emph>, 18, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Aldermanbury, London</tei-emph>; or in Paris, postage paid, to the president of the Society for Christian Morality, 12, rue Taranne.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-head n="France." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">FRANCE.</tei-head>
  <tei-head n="Paris." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">PARIS.</tei-head>
  <tei-head n="Cour de cassation." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">COURT OF CASSATION.</tei-head>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Hearing of <tei-date data-origname="date">22 November</tei-date>. Presided over by <tei-persName ref="#Bstd" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. de Bastard</tei-persName>.</tei-emph></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">APPEAL OF THE CONVICTED OF <tei-placeName ref="#GdA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GRAND'ANSE</tei-placeName> (MARTINIQUE.)</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">After several successive adjournments, the examination of this great case had been set for Saturday, 22 November. During these delays,<tei-pb facs="v1n6f25" n="25" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> M. Prosecutor General Dupin had the documents transmitted to him. It was rumored that he was to speak in this trial, which perhaps has no example in the annals of the supreme court. At the sitting definitively announced, of which we are about to give our readers an account, the bench of the public prosecutor’s office was occupied by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Parant</tei-persName>, advocate-general, the court sitting under the presidency of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. de Bastard</tei-persName>.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">One notes the absence of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Councillor Mérilhou</tei-persName>, whom a painful and very recent loss prevented from attending the hearing. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Councillor Isambert</tei-persName> is also one of the magistrates whom one seeks with anxiety within the court: his seat is empty. It is soon learned that this honorable magistrate is abstaining, and that the Keeper of the Seals and the Prosecutor General have sought his recusal, on the ground that, in a letter to the men of color of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName>, written in his capacity as deputy, M. Isambert had expressed in advance an opinion on one of the grounds of appeal, that of amnesty (1).</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">Many men of color are present at the bar, among whom two are particularly noticed, living examples of the furies of another era, now reproduced a decade later in the events of Grand'Anse. One also sees behind the rail <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Macaulay</tei-persName>, of the Anti-Slavery Society of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">London</tei-placeName>, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. John Scoble</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">James Copper</tei-persName>, members of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">British and Foreign Society for the Abolition of Slavery</tei-orgName>. On the rapporteur’s desk lies the enormous case file, bearing in giant letters these words: “Insurrection de la Grand' Anse”.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Councillor de Ricard</tei-persName> begins his report, the reading of which lasts about three hours. We shall not follow this magistrate through the general outline of the facts that he sketches in broad strokes, and the grounds of appeal that he analyzes with impartiality. The facts are today well known, after all the contradictory publications to which they have given rise; we can do no better than to refer, on this point, to the Memoir of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Me Gatine</tei-persName> that we
    <tei-note data-origname="note">(1) The publicity given to this letter is not, as M. Dupin claims, the fault of M. Isambert. M. Fabien, representative of the men of color of Martinique, to whom the letter was delivered, believed he ought to publish it in the interest of his constituents.</tei-note><tei-pb facs="v1n6f26" n="26" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>announced in our last issue. As for the numerous grounds for cassation, the pleadings that we shall report succinctly and the judgment will make them sufficiently known. On the ground of amnesty, the rapporteur read several documents transmitted to the court by the Minister of the Navy, including in particular a letter from the former governor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dupotet</tei-persName>, denying the orders and full powers he had given to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Captain Montigny</tei-persName>, sent to meet <tei-emph data-origname="emph">the insurrection in order to settle this matter by all suitable means</tei-emph>; then another letter from <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Rear-Admiral Halgan</tei-persName>, the current governor, who was not in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName> at the time of the events of <tei-date data-origname="date">December 1833</tei-date>, and who nonetheless certifies that the insurgents were in no way amnestied. The reading of these documents, after that of the passages from the committal decision and from the indictment itself, which positively acknowledge the fact of the amnesty, is received with a painful sensation.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">After the report and a brief suspension of the hearing, the floor is given to counsel. Mr Gatine, charged with the defense by all the condemned, with the power to associate another defender with him if the needs of the case required it, shares with M Crémieux the burden of this matter. Here is a rapid analysis of the pleading, full of warmth and logic, by Me Gatine:</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“Gentlemen,” he says as he begins, “the appeal of the condemned of Grand'Anse rests on fairly numerous grounds for cassation. In any other circumstance, we would have feared abusing the moments of the court and the reverent attention it deigns to grant us, especially when we come before it to defend men sentenced to death. But here, in this forever deplorable affair, our grounds, however numerous they may be, still remain fewer than the number of capital sentences alone. In the presence of all these scaffolds, by probing this long procedure, we may have been able to point out to you all the nullities that it seemed to present, and your benevolence, we are assured, will not fail us for the rapid development of the proposed grounds.”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“In following the series of operations of the assize court, we had first to address the drawing of the assessors. The first five grounds relate to this phase of the procedure.”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“We shall first make a general observation, under the im<tei-pb facs="v1n6f27" n="27" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>pression of which the grounds seem to us to require assessment.”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“You know it, gentlemen, the colonies do not enjoy the institution of the jury. There one merely adds to the magistrates composing the assize court <tei-emph data-origname="emph">assessors</tei-emph> taken from a college or body of criminal judges existing within the jurisdiction of each assize court. I say criminal judges, for that is the title that suits them: they are at once judges of fact and appliers of the penalty; they have, with few differences of attribution, the same powers as the magistrates themselves.”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“That is the importance of their functions. It makes one grasp the equal importance attached to the operations of the drawing and the formation of the assessors’ list.”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“But that is not all. What the court must remark above all is the composition of the assessors’ college. <tei-emph data-origname="emph">They are recruited exclusively among whites.</tei-emph> No man of color is included, although a great number meet the required conditions. That is, gentlemen, a fact of the highest gravity in the presence of class enmity, before these implacable hatreds that attach to men of color and which, it was said, recently for this very trial, crossed the ocean, pursuing their victims even into your hall (1)! Gentlemen, in their sufferings, men of color often cry out that they have no judges in the colonies. At the very least they do not have judgment <tei-emph data-origname="emph">by their peers</tei-emph>, that common right of French citizens in criminal matters. Ask the white assessors whether the mulatto accused are their peers…. Oh! yes, gentlemen, the drawing of the assessors, the recusals, the formation of the list of four for judgment, these are important formalities!”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“What happened? We shall see.”</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">Here counsel discusses five grounds, relating among other things to the recusal of the sieur <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Duval-Dugué</tei-persName>, who was kept on the list despite the accused, who wished to have him struck out: <tei-q data-origname="q">They were exer<tei-note data-origname="note">(1) <tei-persName data-origname="persName">RICHARD-Lucy</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Lepelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>, who have condemned so many unfortunates in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName>, came to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">France</tei-placeName> with the documents of the trial. They were received by the Keeper of the Seals and by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Dupin</tei-persName>, Prosecutor General. After their visit, M. Dupin sought, before the Court of Cassation, the removal of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Isambert</tei-persName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName>, brother of the Prosecutor General, is the agent of the privileged colonists of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName> <tei-emph data-origname="emph">on a wage</tei-emph> of 20,000 francs <tei-emph data-origname="emph">per year</tei-emph>.</tei-note><tei-pb facs="v1n6f28" n="28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>cising <tei-emph data-origname="emph">peremptory</tei-emph> challenges, said Me Gatine, that is to say, absolute, without examination or discussion, for the law recognizes no others. It is a right for which it asks no account of the accused, no more than it asks account of judges for their convictions. The accused also had to <tei-emph data-origname="emph">confer</tei-emph> in order to exercise their challenges; otherwise they would have been illusory for the greater number. Were they not there <tei-emph data-origname="emph">eighty-eight</tei-emph>! Can one say that each of them enjoyed the right of challenge if no concert was established among them in all the breadth and all the freedom that must belong to the defense!</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“Should one not be astonished as well by the incident that marked the last operation of the drawing? A single name remained in the urn after all the excuses successively admitted, for everyone recoiled before the role of judge in this horrifying trial. The name of the sole assessor remaining was drawn from the urn; it could hardly fail to come out. Was it chance that drew it? Drawing lots is the choice of chance among a number of individuals greater than those that must be chosen; one understands it for a certain number of assessors or jurors; one understands it for a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">plurality</tei-emph>; one does not understand it for a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">unity</tei-emph>. Will it be said that there was no recusal? But it was impossible, for it would have prevented the formation of the list and would necessarily have sent the case to other extraordinary assizes. In sum, and this will not be the least deplorable, eighty-eight accused who were there, plunged for six months into dungeons, were forced either to renounce the exercise of their right of recusal or, by exercising it, to prolong still further the sufferings of their captivity, the anguish of a hundred families; yet the right of recusal is the very right of the defense. Once it was impracticable, the trial itself had become impossible. One could not find judges; all the assessors successively designated by lot recoiled in terror; the accused, by their number, so to speak innumerable, were themselves an impossibility; everything, in the preliminaries of the trial, led to the impossible! It was perhaps a warning from on high; if only it had been heard!”</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Coming to the hearings, counsel pauses on the testimony of the witness Dieudonné Valmont, one of the most important, as the assize court itself declared: <tei-q data-origname="q">“This witness,” says Mr Gatine,<tei-pb facs="v1n6f29" n="29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> “was afflicted with mental alienation, according to a physician’s certificate that is probative; nevertheless his deposition was read. It is not one of the least strange circumstances of this dreadful trial that the introduction of such a document into the proceedings should be used to arrive at the discovery of truth. Do reason, morality, and public honor allow one to make use, in any matter whatsoever, of the deposition of a madman against accused persons? High-ranking magistrates, assessors taken from among the elite of citizens, criminal judges in short, having to decide the life or death of eighty-eight accused, will they seek their convictions in the narratives of a diseased mind! That is what is seen only in the colonies, there where abuse reigns, where the law is nothing.”</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">The court must also examine whether the publicity of the hearings was sufficiently established. This guarantee had here an importance higher still than usual. This unheard-of trial, this great drama with its bloody denouement, which for an entire month unfolded in its monstrous proportions, ought at least to have taken place in the full light of day. If, in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName>, justice, besides its thousand wounds, were also <tei-emph data-origname="emph">occult</tei-emph>, there would no longer be any restraint on abuses. Publicity is still a guarantee for those who no longer have any other.”</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mr Gatine then points out grave irregularities in the most important part of the trial, the framing of the questions of fact and their resolution.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The defenders had asked that the question be put whether many of the accused had not been dragged into the bands <tei-emph data-origname="emph">under constraint</tei-emph>; for, in such a case, the leaders command, the multitude follows them, blind and intelligent. It is a case of excuse provided by law. The assize court of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName> could not dispense with putting the requested question. There lay the salvation of the accused: <tei-q data-origname="q">“In a solemn circumstance,” says counsel, “on an application by the Prosecutor General, in the interest of the law, you judged by decision of <tei-date data-origname="date">10 January 1834</tei-date> that the law was not violated by the putting of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">a question of constraint</tei-emph>. I seize upon that decision dictated by reason and by humanity; I conclude from it that the question lies within the rights of the accused, within the rights of the defense, since the law does not forbid it. Here again, the right of the defense was ignored!”</tei-q></tei-p><tei-pb facs="v1n6f30" n="30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Finally, no penalty could be pronounced on the state of facts as they resulted from the answers given to the questions put. Counsel recalls the questions and the answers; he sets them alongside the provisions of the law; he concludes from them that neither the plot nor the attack imputed to the accused is duly established in all its constituent circumstances. He also notes, after a convincing discussion on this point, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">that the aim and the character of the bands</tei-emph> were not determined. In support of his observation he cites several judgments rendered in the affairs of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Vendée</tei-placeName> and in that of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">rue des Prouvaires</tei-placeName> in <tei-date data-origname="date">1832</tei-date>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“The consequences are palpable,” adds Me Gatine. “The attack committed in bands, the posts or commands in those bands, all facts stripped of the circumstances that criminalize them, are no longer reached by the penal law. Those who underwent the death penalty for those commands or posts could not be struck by it. Those who, for having merely been part of the bands, underwent perpetual expulsion from the colony could not be torn from their families, for article 100 of the colonial penal code, that legislative monstrosity, however discretionary it may be, can evidently be applied only insofar as it concerns <tei-emph data-origname="emph">criminal</tei-emph> bands.”</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mr Gatine concludes in roughly these terms:</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">“There would remain to develop one ground that would dominate all the others, that of amnesty. But to assess that ground, one would have to enter into the examination of the facts, so that the court might see how amnesty was proclaimed as the only possible issue to a military event; how the governor himself, before his immense responsibility, had to have recourse to that amnesty; whether it is true that the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">insurrection of Grand' Anse</tei-emph> was only an explosion of colonial passions; whether it is true, finally, that blind and implacable enmities did all the evil in this affair.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">You would have to, gentlemen, count all these scaffolds, measure with sorrow this unlimited extension given to political accusations; for this is a work of politics, and of the worst, the most intolerant, the most murderous, the politics of the colonists!</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">After this long and laborious discussion, courage would fail us to place again before the eyes of the court so many desolations, <tei-pb facs="v1n6f31" n="31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> so many tears, so much blood already shed by armed force before the action of justice had begun!”</tei-p></tei-q>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Amnesty was the only remedy for all these ills. It was proclaimed by a military chief invested with the powers of the governor, as the indictment itself has acknowledged; and in the presence of that formal admission by the accusers, we scarcely understand that, with the delegations of the current governor, who was not in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName> at the time of the so-called insurrection, one should come to quibble over amnesty for ninety-three condemned! It is in contempt of that amnesty, in contempt of national honor, that so many men would go to perish miserably in exile or in the penal colonies, that so many families would be decimated, heaped pell-mell in this dreadful hecatomb!</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Gentlemen, this ground of amnesty deserves no less than the others the solicitude of the court. But, for our part, we shall not prolong any longer these long observations to which a colleague must still add. What we ask, we can now summarize and say in two words: it is an act of that benevolent vigilance that you do not cease to exercise over your overseas litigants, it is the revision of this trial, the most deplorable that has for a long time desolated the colonies; it is a new examination, new judges. One may look twice when fifteen heads are at stake!</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr Crémieux</tei-persName> then takes the floor: Gentlemen, I take the floor after the pleading you have just heard; it is not that I feel the need to add new arguments to those that have just been set out, but it is to fulfill a duty of conscience and humanity, so that my voice may not be lacking in this hall for these unfortunate men who, from the depths of their dungeons, asked for it as a favor, they who could demand it as a right. Oh! what a dreadful procedure, gentlemen, what a despairing condemnation! What then? The law will offer no means to annihilate forever this frightful decision! What justice, that of the colonies! Not that I wish to inquire whether the condemned were guilty, a competent tribunal has pronounced; but, great God, no mercy, no pity! Fifteen heads promised to the scaffold, <tei-pb facs="v1n6f32" n="32" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>twenty-five unfortunates destined for the penal colony, thirty, forty, what do I know, expelled from the colony forever, and a fearful mass of death sentences in absentia! You remember, gentlemen, the consternation that came to freeze the metropolis at that fatal announcement! And yet, it was possible not to prosecute, not to judge, not to condemn! It was possible, and I go further: condemnation, judgment, and prosecution are struck with illegality. I shall not enter into the examination of the fifteen grounds that have been successively presented to you; but there are two that are, in my eyes, of palpable evidence. One dominates the case, it abolishes the accusation, it strikes it and ruins it at its base, it is <tei-emph data-origname="emph">amnesty</tei-emph>. Amnesty, pledge of peace and reconciliation, support of thrones, glory of princes, amnesty, so sweet to decree, so favorably welcomed by all who bear a generous heart.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">You judged it recently, gentlemen, with those high lights that recommend your supreme jurisdiction: when amnesty has been promised by a chief having authority, and that, on the faith of that amnesty, rebels have surrendered, judicial proceedings are null. Well then! In the case, an amnesty was promised, it was accepted, it was violated! What I assert, I prove by the committal decision. Here are passages that decide the question:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Captain Montigny was charged by the governor to appease the sedition, and <tei-emph data-origname="emph">to employ, to that end, all the means that would seem to him the most suitable.</tei-emph></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Thus, all the governor’s powers were placed in Montigny’s hands. Would one tell us, by chance, that the suitable means were only means of repression and vengeance? Woe to whoever would say such words in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">France</tei-placeName>! Repression after promises, after threats, after summonses, after all promises of humanity; otherwise repression is a crime. Thus <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Montigny</tei-persName> had the power to grant amnesty, he granted it, here is the proof, I read the committal decision:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Montigny</tei-persName> approaches the insurgents with twenty armed men, he summons them to surrender, in the name of the governor, and at these first words a great number throw down their arms. Then <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Montigny</tei-persName> approaches alone at a gallop, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">he declares, according to persons who were within hearing:</tei-emph> for his part he does not recall his <tei-pb facs="v1n6f33" n="33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>expressions well, he declares, in the name of the governor, that if they surrender NOTHING WILL BE DONE TO THEM; immediately, one of the chiefs steps out of the ranks, and <tei-emph data-origname="emph">all the insurgents lay down their arms!</tei-emph></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Nothing will be done to them</tei-emph>, and death, the galleys, and exposure await them! They are amnestied, and they are struck with fury! Amnestied, and what amnesty? Not that which goes to seek the inculpated in prison and sends him away, after the charge, without judgment; but the amnesty of battlefields, the one that stops the shedding of the most precious blood; the one that says: Lay down your arms, do not redden yourself with the blood of your brothers, and the veil of oblivion will cover all. This amnesty is the salvation of all, not only of those whom you pardon, but of those who came to fight them; for, in combat, death reaps on both sides. And you violate this capitulation between brothers!</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Gentlemen, you will not endure it, you will quash a judgment that tramples underfoot what is most sacred in the world, the law of pardon. You will proclaim the rights of amnesty; and we who plead for Frenchmen from a distant colony will profit from this solemn sitting to say again: Amnesty! amnesty! let dungeons and prisons open before it, let citizens forget and forgive, and let a fraternal hand come to clasp the hand of the amnestied! (General movement in the audience.)</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Gentlemen, there is a second ground that likewise entails the quashing of this procedure, namely the violation of article 64 of the penal code, combined with article 359 of the code of criminal instruction. After recalling some of the arguments given by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr Gatine</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr Crémieux</tei-persName> adds: What did the accused say? We ask that a question be put in this form: Were the accused constrained to the crime by a force they could not resist? That question resolved in their favor, there was no longer any crime, and they refuse to put it! The assessors will know that there is no crime if there was force, and they will not declare guilt. Gentlemen, the assessors are the jurors of the colonies, and jurors have no questions of law to resolve, but facts to judge. And in what circumstance do you refuse to put this question? In a case where it concerns an insurrection, a civil war. And who does not know that in such a case the mass <tei-pb facs="v1n6f34" n="34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> follows and fights without understanding? Its will is the will of a few chiefs. Alas! almost always the chiefs escape through betrayal, and the thunderbolt strikes the people obeying the voice of the true guilty!</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I stop, gentlemen, I did not mean to plead, but to call your high wisdom to these two points that carry the case. Let the scaffolds and the chains fall, let the judgments of exile and expulsion perish! Oh! I know well that fifteen heads will not fall; the king, I know well, will not suffer this <tei-emph data-origname="emph">judicial butchery</tei-emph>; but nonetheless it is to death that the judgment destines them! The voice that implored me is <tei-emph data-origname="emph">vox morituri</tei-emph>. Sacred is the prayer of a condemned man, especially of a political condemned; I have answered it as far as it depended on me; the salvation of all these unfortunates is in your hands, they will be saved!”</tei-p></tei-q>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Parant</tei-persName>, advocate-general, contests successively all the grounds of the appeal. As regards amnesty, he seeks to demonstrate that, under the colonial ordinances, the governor did not have the right to grant it.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">It is six o’clock in the evening; the court postpones the delivery of its judgment to <tei-date data-origname="date">Monday 24</tei-date>. All day Sunday is spent deliberating. At the opening of the Monday sitting, the court again postpones its judgment to <tei-date data-origname="date">Thursday 27</tei-date>. On that day, finally, the court sitting, Mr. President reads a long judgment rejecting the appeal.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">A painful impression follows this unexpected result. All those who had followed the court’s sittings with anxiety withdraw in a bleak silence.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">One wonders what the governor of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName> will do with his fifteen heads.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">An application for pardon was immediately filed by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr Gatine</tei-persName>. We shall make known this document, which completes the defense of our compatriots.<tei-pb facs="v1n6f35" n="35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/></tei-p></tei-div>
         
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-head n="Opinion des journaux sur le ministre de la marine et des colonies, du ministère des trois jours." data-origname="head" data-origatts="n">OPINION OF THE NEWSPAPERS ON THE MINISTER OF THE NAVY AND THE COLONIES, OF THE “THREE-DAY MINISTRY.”</tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Although the “three-day ministry” is now as if it had never been, we believe it appropriate to give here the opinion of the newspapers on one of the most inconsistent men of that party of political <tei-emph data-origname="emph">eunuchs</tei-emph>, called the third party, which was so cruelly mystified in the strange governmental comedy played in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Paris</tei-placeName> in the first fortnight of November. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName>, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">the savant</tei-emph>, as they say, interests us for more than one reason; for if we no longer have the happiness of having him as Minister of the Navy and the Colonies, he is nonetheless said to remain delegate of the white colonists of Martinique, with emoluments of 20,000 francs.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">OPINION OF THE NEWSPAPERS ON THE MINISTER OF THE NAVY AND THE COLONIES, OF THE “THREE-DAY MINISTRY.”</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Although the “three-day ministry” is now as if it had never been, we believe it appropriate to give here the opinion of the newspapers on one of the most inconsistent men of that party of political <tei-emph data-origname="emph">eunuchs</tei-emph>, called the third party, which was so cruelly mystified in the strange governmental comedy played in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Paris</tei-placeName> in the first fortnight of November. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName>, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">the savant</tei-emph>, as they say, interests us for more than one reason; for if we no longer have the happiness of having him as Minister of the Navy and the Colonies, he is nonetheless said to remain delegate of the white colonists of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName>, with emoluments of 20,000 francs. It is therefore good and useful to know what to think of this singular personage, who meddles in everything without suspecting anything.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Here is the opinion of the capital’s newspapers on the appointment of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName> to the Ministry of the Navy and the Colonies:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">LE COURRIER FRANÇAIS.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Charles Dupin</tei-persName>, who, by having himself designated under the title of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">savant</tei-emph>, has almost succeeded in making the title of savant ridiculous, who has made proverbial the boredom inspired by his tribune speeches, whose disinterestedness is attested by the accumulation of twelve or fifteen posts, whose borrowed learning, diluted in large volumes, has pushed back the limits of charlatanism, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">M. Charles Dupin</tei-emph> was, of all the men who could be chosen, the most antipathic to the naval corps, the one whose elevation was bound to cause the most discontent. What was hoped for in appointing him? Certainly, it was not thought to strengthen the cabinet with a man of the tribune; it was not thought to endow the navy with a specialist. Perhaps it was wished to reward the author of the motion that brought about the resignation and retirement of Lafayette; in that respect, he has well merited the Palais-Royal, and he may find that the reward was long in coming. No doubt too, one counts on attaching the naturally precarious and variable support of his brother; but even if that support were irrevocably acquired to the new cabinet, it would not compensate for what the presence of M. Charles Dupin brings with it: disfavor, unpopularity, <tei-pb facs="v1n6f36" n="36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>and, it must be said, ridicule. It is said that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. de Rigny</tei-persName>, accustomed to being called the victor of Navarino, finds it somewhat hard to fall under the orders of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Louis-Philippe</tei-persName> indeed subjects the humility of his former minister to a rude test.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The influence of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Dupin</tei-persName> the elder will have contributed to having the combination adopted in which his brother found a place. For anyone who would judge the President of the Chamber by his parliamentary importance, his conduct, once again, would remain without explanation; as for us, it causes us no surprise. If <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Dupin</tei-persName> truly had political views and an ambition somewhat lofty, he would have avoided delivering the party of which he believes himself the leader to the public’s disdain and to the laughter of his adversaries. Instead of imposing the inflated nullity of his brother on colleagues who together brought neither too great a personal authority nor too great a sum of talents, he would have boldly undertaken it himself, and would have made himself the orator of that ministry which is now at the knees of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Sauzet</tei-persName>. One may feel indulgence toward oneself, but one cannot prevent a ministry that has added <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName> to itself from being devoted to ridicule.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">LE BON SENS.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The President of the Chamber of Deputies put his brother at the navy as a matter of family convenience. In this affair, there is no one to pity but the sailors, who will have to endure the pompous insufficiency of the successor of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Jacob</tei-persName>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName> no doubt has a tireless organ and will give very verbose orders to admirals and to all naval officers; but the talent he has for making even the most resigned listeners flee the Chamber is a privilege that is not very parliamentary.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">There are people who know how to profit from their position, however difficult and humiliating it may be. We have said that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName> had resigned none of his employments, whose number is almost incalculable; that he had even kept the title of delegate of the colonists to the Minister of the Navy: he did better than that, he tried, immediately after giving his forced resignation, to have himself granted one of the richest sinecures, that of director of naval matériel. Having presented the ordinance of appointment to the king, the latter observed <tei-pb facs="v1n6f37" n="37" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>to him that he would be obliged to countersign the ordinance himself; whereupon the accumulator was forced to renounce the 20,000 francs of salary he had coveted.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">LE MESSAGER.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Seriously considered in its whole as in its individualities, does the new cabinet represent anything other than the court, which seems to have sought, outside all the required conditions, flexible persons for its immutable thought? Can one imagine an officer of maritime engineering, constructor of a single vessel which took on water on all sides at its first contact with the sea, commanding our fleets and directing our colonies?…..</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">LE NATIONAL.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Since we are in the time of devotions and sacrifices, we would like to know whether provision will be made for the replacement of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. le duc de Trévise</tei-persName> as Grand Chancellor of the Legion of Honor. We advise <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Mortier</tei-persName> to imitate the foresight of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName>. This skilled calculator, delegate, as is known, of the colonists of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName> to the Ministry of the Navy, had judged it appropriate to remain delegate to his own person, with emoluments of 20,000 francs per year.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The talents and the salaries accumulated by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Charles Dupin</tei-persName> have more than once been displayed before the electoral colleges and the committees of the Chamber. But this time, it must be admitted, M. Charles Dupin outdid himself.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">REVUE DES DEUX MONDES.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">France</tei-placeName> cannot always be tossed between <tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Thiers</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Guizot</tei-persName>, or between <tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Thiers</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dupin</tei-persName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Dupin</tei-persName> already sees how poorly the idea succeeded that he had of sending his brother <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Raton</tei-persName> to pull for him the chestnuts of ministerial fire. Thus, if <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Dupin</tei-persName> manages to form, before the session, in his uncertain head, a sort of political system, if he arrives at forming a just idea of the amnesty he wants, if he succeeds in reconciling his hatred for his friends on the left with his aversion for his friends of the castle, in making agree his taste for popularity and his contempt for the press and for opinion, if he comes to unite all these <tei-pb facs="v1n6f38" n="38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>things, quite reconcilable as one sees, we shall soon have a third-party ministry, a ministry <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dupin</tei-persName>, a unique ministry.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Following the resignation of the “three-day” ministers, the cabinet has been reconstituted as follows:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Marshal Mortier</tei-persName>, Minister of War, President of the Council.
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Thiers</tei-persName>, Minister of the Interior.
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Admiral de Rigny</tei-persName>, Minister of Foreign Affairs;
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Humann</tei-persName>, Minister of Finance; 
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Guizot</tei-persName>, Minister of Public Instruction;
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Duchâtel</tei-persName>, Minister of Commerce;
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Persil</tei-persName>, Minister of Justice;
<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Admiral Duperré</tei-persName>, Minister of the Navy and the Colonies.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">-The ministry of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Lord Melbourne</tei-persName> has given way to the Tory-Wellington ministry. The <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Duke of Wellington</tei-persName> is First Lord of the Treasury, and, as principal Secretary of State, holds the seals of the departments of the interior, foreign affairs, and the colonies. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Sir Robert Peel</tei-persName> occupies the functions of Chancellor of the Exchequer.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The following appointments have just taken place in the colonial judiciary and administration:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. E. Reizet</tei-persName>, licentiate in law, has been appointed judge of first instance at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Basse-Terre</tei-placeName> (<tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>), replacing <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. de Waldemar</tei-persName>, who has resigned.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Ledentu</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Aubin</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Bigeon</tei-persName> have been appointed privy councillors, full members, of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName> for the years 1855 and 1836.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">MM. Pedemonte, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Belost</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Bellaud-Descommunes</tei-persName> have been appointed privy councillors, alternates of the same colony.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"> -We read in the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Journal de la Marine</tei-emph>:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The appointment of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Rivoil</tei-persName>, former solicitor, to the post of auditing councillor at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Guirne</tei-placeName> has been the object of lively protests. The laws governing the colonies required that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Rivoil</tei-persName> be a licentiate in law to fulfill the functions entrusted to him. It is said that at the Ministry of the Navy they are very dissatisfied at having been deceived on this point, and that they are resolved to reverse this appointment.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">-<tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Famiral Halgan</tei-persName>, Governor of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Martinique</tei-placeName>, who was not in the colony at the time of the Grand'Anse affair, was consulted by the Minister of the Navy on the question of whether there had been, on the part of the colonial authority, a promise of amnesty made to the men of color condemned in this affair. The admiral’s answer was negative; and the Ministry of the Navy hastened to add to the case file the dispatch of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Halgan</tei-persName>. The Court of Cassation did not admit the ground pleaded for the condemned, drawn from this promise of amnesty; the appeal of these victims was rejected!</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">-Another dispatch from Admiral <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Halgan</tei-persName> to the Minister of the Navy pointed out several acts of cruelty by a colonist, who would have caused several of his slaves to die in torments and horrible tortures, says the admiral.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">We learn that this colonist, who had fled during the first proceedings brought against him, surrendered, was tried by his brothers and friends, and acquitted, as was to be expected, unanimously by seven votes.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">-We read in the second issue of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Abolitionist</tei-emph>:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">In the correspondence of the English commissioners with the government, one gathers the sad proof that the infamous commerce of the slave trade is still carried on with activity and that the means employed by the government to prevent it are wholly insufficient. The number of slavers captured by the English on the west coast of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Africa</tei-placeName>, and brought to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Sierra Leone</tei-placeName> to be sold, amounts to five, namely: four Spanish and one Portuguese. They had on board at the time of their capture 1,884 Negroes; 185 died in the interval before the sale of the vessels. There thus remained to be restored to freedom 1,701 Africans.</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">We are firmly persuaded, say the commissioners, that the trade continues under the Spanish flag with as much perseverance as in the past. We are distressed, however, to have to announce that this infamous traffic soils the French flag.</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The latest news we have from the foreign colonies is of <tei-date data-origname="date">12 November</tei-date>. On that date, the greatest tranquility reigned in the Antilles; the newly emancipated slaves worked peacefully at cultivation on all the plantations.</tei-p>

            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">William Lamb, deuxième vicomte de Melbourne</tei-persName>
